newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares end weaker, seen staying that way.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares end weaker, seen staying that way.

text.p: Singapore shares drifted down on Wednesday, and dealers said they saw no signs of a rally in the short term.
"The market is settling into a trading range and will stick to it for some time," said one. The Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) fell 13.33 points to end the day at 2,047.89.
With no compelling reason for investors to jump into the market, sideways shifts and downward drifts were seen as the main features in coming weeks, another dealer said.
"I don't expect to see a recovery until the latter part of June," the dealer said.
Small capitalised stocks saw most of the action on a during which 128.1 million shares changed hands to give 211 losers and 126 gainers.
Benefun International and New Toyo both saw more than six million shares traded to end the day at Hong Kong $1.45 -- up a cent -- and Singapore $0.895 -- up S$0.015 -- respectively.

Shares in DBS Land reacted badly to Tuesday's announcement of a 92 million share placement capital raising exercise, falling briefly below the S$4.75 placement price before gaining a cent to end the day down 24 cents at S$4.76.
